results.name: Array read by antidiagonals upwards: a(i,0) = 2, i >= 0; a(i,1) = i+2, i >= 0; a(i,j) = (i+2) * a(i,j-1) - a(i,j-2), for i >= 0, j > 1.
comment: Note the similarity in form of the recursive steps in the array definition above and the polynomial definition under FORMULA.
link: William W. Collier, Experimental Mathematics on Wisteria Tables, Talk to Poughkeepsie ACM Chapter.
formula: Let k be an integer, and let r1 and r2 be the roots of x + 1/x = k. Then f(k,n) = r1^n + r2^n is an integer, for integer n >= 0. Theorem: a(i,j) = f(i+2,j), for i,j >= 0. Proof: See the Collier link.
p[0](n) = 2, for n >= 0 ( [ and ] demark subscripts).

p[j](n) = p[j-1](n) * p[1](n) - p[j-2](n), for j > 1, n >= 0. The coefficients of these polynomials occur as the even numbered, upward diagonals in the OEIS Wiki link. Conjecture: a(i,j) = p[j](i), i,j >= 0.
